overview.name: Programme overview
overview.lead: Building a society that works: Continuity and change
overview.paragraph:
The Presidential Employment Stimulus was established in response to the devastating economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Its aim is to create jobs and strengthen livelihoods, supporting meaningful work while the labour market recovers. It also recognises that this is a moment of opportunity for change – for new ways of working, and new forms of innovation, in response to a crisis of unemployment that pre-dates the pandemic. In Phase One it was able to deliver over 500,000 jobs and opportunties in just five months, with implementation of many of these programmes still continuing. Phase Two builds on this, with both continuity and change, through the introduction of a range of new programmes, all with the same aim: to build back better. 
This dashboard tracks the performance of all programmes contributing to the Presidential Employment Stimulus. It reflects work in progress, with the data updated regularly.
overview.footer_paragraph: The Presidential Employment Stimulus data is subject to ongoing verification and audit. The numbers reported may change based on final verification and audit outcomes.

departments.name: Agriculture, Land Reform and Rural Development

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_details.detail: The department received rollovers for unspent funds and has issued second vouchers to voucher recipients from Phase One that qualified. They continue to verify applicants, which requires validating the farmer activity reported. The department faced challenges with certain suppliers that were charging more than the pre-agreed prices for inputs, taking a cut of the vouchers or disbursing cash instead of inputs for production and has suspended and blacklisted a number of suppliers on this basis.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_details.detail: 51,559 voucher beneficiaries from Phase 1 have been issued second vouchers by DALRRD in Phase 2. These figures are not reflected here because these are not new beneficiaries - but certainly, this is augmenting the impact of the support. 133,000 new applications have also been received and are being processed. DALRRD has however faced implementation challenges. Firstly, the USSD system for applications for vouchers was completely oversubscribed the day it was launched. This reflects the scale of need. The second major challenge was abuse of the voucher scheme by private sector suppliers, with many taking a cut of the voucher value. In response to complaints, the department suspended the scheme and is putting systems in place to prevent this problem. To expedite verification of applicants, a partnership is in final approval stages with the Solidarity Fund, to allow sharing of information.

departments.lead: Expanding support to farmers and protecting food value chains
departments.paragraph: The pandemic illustrated the vulnerability of our food production and distribution systems. Although exempt from the strictest lockdown regulations, the sector faced severe challenges with disruptions to production and marketing experienced by many small-scale farmers. In Phase One, the Presidential Employment Stimulus supported subsistence farmers by providing production input vouchers. Applications were done on a USSD platform, providing DALRRD with a geo-spatially referenced data-base of subsistence farmers for the first time. Agricultural graduates were used to do on-site verification of applicants, collecting additional data that provides a basis for future support also. Phase Two builds on this, to create pathways out of poverty for subsistence farmers, with follow-up support to farmers that participated in Phase One, as well as further roll-out.

departments.name: Basic Education

implementation_detail.detail: The department placed education assistants in schools across the country. These young people provided crucial support to teachers in the classroom and performed administrative tasks. Although due to conclude at the end of March, most provincial departments were able to extend the education assistants contracts for another month to align with the end of the school term in April. The programme has concluded this Phase. The department has compiled a comprehensive review, that has informed improvements  in Phase Two.

The department exceeded its target for placement of general assistants in all schools across the country. The general assistants supported maintenance and security at schools and other basic needs. Similar to the education assistants, most provincial departments took a decision to extend contracts until end of April.

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: This programme protected vulnerable teacher posts across the schooling system. Although initially targeted at quintile 4 and 5 schools, the support was targeted to all other schools in recognition of support required in poorer schools as well. This funding support was undersubscribed and so where possible, provinces transferred the funds to support the extension of school assistants by another month.

In addition to orientation and training on Covid procedures, DBE is rolling out training on digital skills and financial management to all participants. Education Assistants are also being trained to support core curriculum outcomes, with cohorts being trained as Reading Champions, as E-cadres and Child and Youth Care Workers.
In addition to the training for all participants, some of the General Assistants are being trained as Sports and Enrichment Assitants and on maintenance tasks.

departments.paragraph: The Basic Education Employment Intervention (BEEI) placed over 300,000 young people as assistants in schools across the country in Phase One. Phase Two builds on this success, with a target of 287,000 school assistants in two categories. Education Assistants are supporting teachers in the classroom. These posts require a matric, with graduates prioritised. General Assistants are assisting with tasks such as school maintenance, security, food gardens and after-school care. The BEEI has provided a new example of how public employment programmes can go rapidly to scale, creating meaningful work at decent standards for young people, while delivering real public value. In Phase One, 94,6% of 60,000 teachers and principals surveyed believed it added value to curriculum outcomes and wanted it to continue. It also has the advantage of a highly equitable spatial footprint that reaches even the most remote and marginalised communities - because every community has schools.

departments.name: Communications and Digital Technologies

implementation_detail.detail: Detailed technical design work is underway to prepare for pilot implementation of the Broadband Access Fund.

departments.paragraph: The Presidential Employment Stimulus will harness the job-creating potential of digital connectivity by supporting the pilot phase of a Broadband Access Fund as part of Phase 2 of SA Connect. This Fund will develop a well-governed set of technology-agnostic and performance-based capex incentives to extend direct household and public broadband access to low income households. This will leverage private sector capacity to enable last-mile access to affordable, high-quality broadband in areas where providers currently do not have a sufficient incentive to expand coverage. The Broadband Access Fund will provide a “connection subsidy” with conditions related to the quality of connection as well as affordability.

departments.name: Cooperative Governance

implementation_detail.detail: The Municipal Infrastructure Support Agency (MISA) appointed a service provider to deliver capacity development for the use of labour intensive construction methods in 15 municipalities. This includes improvements to reporting within EPWP and assisting in project design for the next financial year to incorporate labour intensive methods in infrastructure delivery. This always meant that results would only start to be evident in the new financial year - and we are seeing them now. Capacity support continues and additional municipalities have asked to come on board.

metrics.name: MISA: Innovation in seperation at source and treatment solutions

implementation_detail.programme_name: MISA: Innovation in seperation at source and treatment solutions
implementation_detail.detail: The programme is supporting two cohorts of municipalities.  Programme implementation for the first cohort has begun, with municipalities advancing PPE and other working materials to allow a rapid start. MISA has decided to expand the rollout from the initial target of 25 municipalities to 45 municipalities. On-boarding of the second cohort of municipalities is in process.

departments.lead: New approaches to solid waste management
departments.paragraph: Through the Municipal Infrastructure Support Agency, COGTA is experimenting with new ways to tackle the challenge of solid waste in 25 municipalities, targeting 85% rural municipalities. These approaches will identify collection, sorting and recycling options and explore revenue generation opportunities for community enterprises, by  looking at the entire waste value chain, with a focus on community awareness. The programme aims not only to create jobs but also to support 100 small enterprises. MISA also continues to support the application of labour-intensive methods in infrastructure in 15 municipalities, that formed part of Phase One, with changes to contracting starting to deliver stronger employment outcomes.

departments.name: Department of Women, Youth and Persons with Disabilities

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

departments.paragraph: The department is supporting two programmes under the Presidential Youth Employment Intervention, namely the National Youth Service and the Youth Enterprise Fund. The revitalised National Youth Service will create opportunities for young people to contribute meaningfully to their communities, develop critical skills required to participate effectively in the economy, build confidence and expand their networks and social capital. The Presidential Youth Service program is structured to support service work for 16-hours a week and will channel young people’s energy into advancing social cohesion, nation building and development. It has a strong focus on supporting complementary income-earning opportunities. The Youth Enterprise Fund will be implemented by the National Youth Development Agency and will  build on the ‘1,000 SME’s in 100 days’ programme of the agency.

departments.name: Employment and Labour

metrics.name: Employment counseling to facilitate placement of workseekers

implementation_detail.programme_name: Employment counseling to facilitate placement of workseekers
implementation_detail.detail: The recruitment of interns is underway. They will support counseling services at Department of Labour Centres, including on-line counseling that will be enabled by the new Employment Services website due to launch in April.

The appointment of an eco-system manager for the national Pathway Management Network is in process. The Jobs Fund call for proposals for the Innovation Fund of the national Pathway Management Network closed on 1 November and successful applicants will be announced shortly.

departments.paragraph: The national Pathway Management Network is a flagship programme of the Presidential Youth Employment Intervention (PYEI). It brings together many partners in a coordinated system that enables young people to find pathways and successfully transition from learning to earning at scale.  Led by the Department of Employment and Labour, the national Pathway Management Network links young people to opportunities and support, identifies and addresses barriers, and supports the creation of opportunities also. With support from the stimulus, an eco-system manager for the PMN is being appointed and an Innovation Fund for the PMN is being supported, through the Jobs Fund. The Department of Labour is also supporting  250 labour counsellors across various labour centres in the country, to assist employers to clearly specify their job requirements and to build competency profiles that will enable effective placement of work seekers as well as support to upskilling of candidates where necessary.

departments.name: Forestry, Fisheries and Environment

metrics.name: Cleaning and greening - war on waste with municipalities

implementation_detail.programme_name: Cleaning and greening - war on waste with municipalities
implementation_detail.detail: The programme planned to undertake cleaning activities and indigenous tree planting. Performance has been negatively affected by procurement delays.

metrics.name: Department of Fisheries: War on Waste at Harbours and landing sites

implementation_detail.programme_name: Department of Fisheries: War on Waste at Harbours and landing sites
implementation_detail.detail: Performance was negatively affected by procurement delays.

metrics.name: Oceans and Coast: Source to Sea

implementation_detail.programme_name: Oceans and Coast: Source to Sea
implementation_detail.detail: Project faced procurement challenges.

metrics.name: Groen Sebenzas, weather service - graduate programme

implementation_detail.programme_name: Groen Sebenzas, weather service - graduate programme
implementation_detail.detail: Graduate interns were mentored in natural resource project management and some did fieldwork towards further qualifications in restoration ecology.
The infrastructure in 11 national botanical gardens and 2 zoological gardens was maintained.
7 facilities in iSimangaliso were maintained and upgraded, 36 kms of fencing was maintained, with roads maintenance undertaken also.
Solar water heaters were installed in Addo, Augrabies and Golden Gate, with solar plants in Tankwa in process. 33 SMEs were supported to undertake the work, which included 100 small renovations.

metrics.name: Catchment management and strategic water sources

implementation_detail.programme_name: Catchment management and strategic water sources
implementation_detail.detail: The programme focused on the rehabilitation of catchment areas and strategic water resources in protected areas. This involved clearing alien invasive species (which reduce water availability and biodiversity) and limiting bush encroachment (which can reduce grazing capacity by up to 80%). The PES enabled clearing of alien invasive species from 29,414 hectares with follow up cleaning on 141 123 hectares.
Support to 19 traditional authorities on biodiversity, conservation and land rehabilitation was envisaged but faced implementation challenges.

This programme focussed on improving the sustainability of  plantations and indigenous forests and the development of forestry enterprises and also on support to disaster risk reduction in relation to veld and forest fires.
Youth living adjacent to protected areas are involved in facilities maintenance.
This programme is supporting sustainable harvesting of indigenous plants and supporting planting for sustainable supply. The revised TORs for a project management are being advertised.
This project has not yet started.
Facilities and infrastructure maintenance will be undertaken. Contract preparation is still in process.

departments.paragraph: The work undertaken in environmental, forestry and fishery programmes will touch the length and breadth of the country, from coast to coast, including bushveld, grassland, fynbos, wetlands, mountains, water bodies, catchment areas  – and urban areas, too. The work undertaken affects the air we breathe, the water we drink, the energy we use and the food we eat, supporting a wealth of biodiversity resources and ecological systems essential to life on earth and to the future of the planet. In phase two a major part of the programme focuses on work with SANBI.

departments.name: Health

implementation_detail.detail: The department faced severe constraints related to rollout in the timeframes.
The department faced severe constraints related to rollout in the timeframes.

The programme concluded at the end of March 2021 and exceeded its target for job creation for nurses. The appointed nurses provided a range of primary health care services in public facilities. Several provinces planned to continue to fund further recruitments to support the roll-out of the COVID-19 vaccination programme.
The exceeded its target for appointed auxiliary nurses. These nurses supported various services in public health facilities as part of the response to COVID-19. The programme concluded in March 2021.
Implementation is currently underway.

metrics.name: Support Port Health Services with  Covid screening

departments.lead: Primary Health Care is at the frontline of the battle against Covid-19
departments.paragraph: As the world responded to the COVID-19 pandemic, the critical role that health workers play to enhance the resilience of the national health care system has been foregrounded. This programme will augment the numbers of community health workers,  outreach team leaders for supervision, nurses and auxiliary nurses as well as supporting Covid screening services in Port Authorities.

departments.name: Higher Education

metrics.name: PYEI/National Skills Fund: Pay for Performance model for digital skills

implementation_detail.programme_name: PYEI/National Skills Fund: Pay for Performance model for digital skills
implementation_detail.detail: The Request for Proposals for ecosystem facilitators has been issued  and is under adjudication in the National Skills Fund.
Universities South Africa (USAf) is the implementation partner, with the terms of the programme currently being finalised.

departments.lead: A 'pay for performance' model for digital skills - and graduate placements in Universities
departments.paragraph:
In support of the Presidential Youth Employment Intervention (PYEI), and in partnership with the National Skills Fund, DHET is testing a 'pay for performance' model for digital skills training, in which placement in jobs at the end of the training is a critical performance factor. 
DHET is also supporting a graduate placement programme in universities - because even for graduates, lack of work experience creates barriers to labour market entry. These placements are for work that allows graduates to apply their skills in relation to their field of study, in order to directly enhance relevant work experience. University departments will be invited to create meaningful opportunities for graduates and in so doing increase their research and academic support capacity.

departments.name: National Treasury

metrics.name: Neighbourhood Development Partnership: PEPS for Metros Programme

implementation_detail.programme_name: Neighbourhood Development Partnership: PEPS for Metros Programme
implementation_detail.detail: Eight metros submited proposals and the adjudication process is complete. Implementation has been dependent on the Adjustment Budget of the Division of Revenue Act being signed - now that this has happened, implementation is starting and will continue to June/July.

departments.lead: Innovation in Public Employment Programmes in the Metro's
departments.paragraph: National Treasury’s Neighbourhood Development Partnership Programme has opened a Neighbourhood Development Partnership Grant window for Public Employment Programmes (PEPs) in the metros. This emphasises the creation of meaningful forms of work that respond to community priorities, encouraging partnerships with non-state actors and co-funding from the private sector. Metros are encouraged to innovate in the forms of work undertaken, to maximise the benefit for participants as well as the social, environmental and/or economic impact. Proposals from eight metros are being supported, with the work undertaken including urban agriculture, placemaking, support to homeless people, catchment management, digitisation of city records and more.

departments.name: Public Works and Infrastructure

implementation_details.detail: This programme was quick of the mark and placed graduates into different facilities management and infrastructure management programmes,  exceeding its targets. The department was able to extend contracts for all graduates for an additional five months after the envisaged end in March 2021.

departments.paragraph: In Phase One, unemployed graduates were placed in programmes such as water and energy efficiency, Welisizwe Rural Bridges programme, facilities management, waste management and real estate management within DPWI. The programme exceeded its target and was able to extend contracts for all graduates for an additional five months at the end of Phase One.  The programme is not part of Phase Two.

departments.name: Science and Innovation

implementation_detail.detail: Programme participants were responsible for building social compacts to initiate behaviour change interventions at community level during the Covid-19 pandemic. The programme has concluded.

The programme exceeded the planned target due to the addition of a food garden project that required additional labour. Overall, 20 project sites were implemented with teams working across the catchment area on different environmental work in different parts of the river. A team of young graduates focussed on making sense of the river health data, and gathered stories from communities to compile into a State of the Rivers report, in partnership with Umgeni Water. This has now been completed.

Placement of graduates was affected by university system closures which meant students could not register and provide proof as part of the application process within initial timeframes but these challenges were overcome.

The programme experienced several challenges with securing hosts for the graduates which led to delays in the two-phased recruitment process. However, the WRC was able to place graduates with various hosts. Phase 2 graduates have been inducted and will also commence their workplace experience soon.

The Enviro-Champs programme is continuing from Phase 1 and is currently ramping up recruitment, in partnership with 14 organisations. Training of participants has begun. They are using an app to track river health.

In addition to work exposure, this programme now includes an entrepreneurship incubator with 300 graduates; 100 graduates from Phase One who performed well are receiving career planning and coaching to prepare them for placements.
Some learners from Phase One are now being supported to undertake the practical training required to complete their qualifications, while recruitment of new participants is also in process.

departments.paragraph: The DSI will continue to support a range of citizen science skills. Graduates are continuing to empower communities in the Duzi-Umgeni Catchment to monitor – and improve - water quality. Science graduates are being placed by the Water Research Commission and experiential training is being provided by the CSIR. In phase two the programme has introduced enterpreneurship training for graduates and mentorship training for participants who performed well in phase one.

departments.name: Social Development

implementation_detail.detail: The programme faced significant delays and challenges and was not implemented.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: The ECD Employment Stimulus Relief Fund (ECD –ESRF) has been verifying and approving applicants since the end of February 2021. Provincial departments were required to pause payments to beneficiaries at the end March as relief funds were only available for the 2020/21 financial year. Due to delays in the approval of applications and transfer of funds to beneficiaries, only 10% had received payments by the end of March 2021. Payments resumed in October 2021, after rollovers were approved. The process is continuing and progress has been made.

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: Social workers appointed through the programme provided essential social services during the pandemic. When the programme concluded at the end of March 2021, some provinces managed to absorb social workers into permanent positions.

metrics.name: Appointment of social workers to assist SASSA with backlogs

implementation_detail.programme_name: Appointment of social workers to assist SASSA with backlogs
implementation_detail.detail: The programme has to date exceeded its target has employed 3099 social workers.
The NDA will partner with 100 Civil Society Oraganizations for the programme supporting community service activities.

metrics.name: ECD Employment Stimulus: Complete payments overdue from Phase 1

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: ECD Employment Stimulus: Complete payments overdue from Phase 1
implementation_detail.detail: The programme experienced significant challenges in Phase 1. A different service provider is currently being appointed to assist with implementation. Verification led to slow payments by provinces, help desks have been set up to mitigate this. Provinces are also assisting applicants to open bank accounts. While the rollout of payments has increased, these are still reported as part of Phase 1 because they are paid from rollover funds.

departments.paragraph: Support planned for the ECD sector in Phase One did not reach all of those who were eligible. In Phase Two, the intention is to remedy these backlogs. This is undertaken partly by the use of roll-over funds, but with these augmented in Phase Two to ensure full coverage of eligible applicants is possible.

departments.name: Sports, Arts and Culture

implementation_detail.detail: The lockdown restrictions and the fact that most facilities were closed led to low demand from National Federations. However, this programme has been able to start implementing as regulations allow increased sporting activity.

metrics.name: Banking with art, connecting Lives - National Museum Bloemfontein

implementation_detail.programme_name: Banking with art, connecting Lives - National Museum Bloemfontein
implementation_detail.detail: The programme has concluded. The approved visual artists created artworks for consideration by the Art Bank of South Africa as part of economic recovery.

metrics.name: Assistance with business growth strategies and marketing plans - South African Cultural Observatory

implementation_detail.programme_name: Assistance with business growth strategies and marketing plans - South African Cultural Observatory
implementation_detail.detail: This project has been implemented by the South African Cultural Observatory (SACO), with Harambee as a partner. Artists have been trained on management and marketing skills by graduates, with both learning valuable lessons from the interaction.

metrics.name: Public Art, towards a people's culture - Community Arts Centres

implementation_detail.programme_name: Public Art, towards a people's culture - Community Arts Centres
implementation_detail.detail: This programme faced implementation challenges.

metrics.name: Audit of national museums - South African Heritage Resources Agency

implementation_detail.programme_name: Audit of national museums - South African Heritage Resources Agency
implementation_detail.detail: The programme appointed young people to conduct audits of memorials, monuments and statues around the country.  Approximately 1600 memorials, monuments and statues were recorded across the country. The programme extended participants for an additional month until end of April to complete fieldwork.

metrics.name: Digitisation of records - National Library of South Africa

implementation_detail.programme_name: Digitisation of records - National Library of South Africa
implementation_detail.detail: The programme extended the contracts of appointed participants until June 2021 to allow for completion of the work.
The programme was extended until June 2021 and has been crucial in enabling the NARSSA to build capacity on digitisation and seeks to digitise one million records.

metrics.name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Arts Council

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Arts Council
implementation_detail.detail: The National Arts Council's (NAC) allocated awards that exceeded the total available funds for the programme. In an attempt to remedy this, awards already made were withdrawn and grant amounts revised downwards, creating much unhappiness for those negatively affected. The NAC instituted an investigation into the PESP management process, which has reported. Meanwhile, implementation has continued with the scale of awards made exceeding the NAC's target. Implementation of diverse creative and cultural activities will continue until the end of the March 2022.

metrics.name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Film and Video Foundation

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Film and Video Foundation
implementation_detail.detail: The NFVF call for proposals was oversubscribed with a total of 891 applications received that could have created in excess of  48 000 jobs. Over 200 awards have been made, supporting a wide range of forms of local content creation in the audio-visual sector. Many of these are still in production, with completion scheduled for the end of March 2022.

metrics.name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Arts Council

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Arts Council
implementation_detail.detail: The call for proposals for the job retention component of the stimulus was undersubscribed. Unallocated funds from job retention were reallocated to augment the funds available to support art and culture practitioners.

metrics.name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Film and Video Foundation

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Film and Video Foundation
implementation_detail.detail: The call for proposals for the job retention component of the stimulus was undersubscribed. Unallocated funds from job retention were reallocated to augment the funds available to support art and culture practitioners.

metrics.name: Job retention in sport sector - Sport Trust

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in sport sector - Sport Trust
implementation_detail.detail: The programme was oversubscribed and 65 organisations received support to retain jobs in the sector. The largest component was support to the golf sector to retain and create jobs for caddies.
Museum workshops for the public were conducted in December but one event was cancelled due to Covid-19.
The Hip Hop museum programme implementation is on track. All researchers for the programme have been recruited, while construction workers and designers have already started their duties.
Digitization of artefacts started in December 2021 and archiving started in November.

departments.lead: Preserving our heritage-support to the District 6, Hip-Hop and Phanzi Museums
departments.paragraph: In Phase One, the focus of the programme was on supporting the cultural, creative and sports sectors throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. Support was provided through grants to the National Arts Council and the National Film and Video Foundation, along with support to a range of public employment programmes supported by the department. In Phase Two, the programme is focused on support to the District Six, Hip Hop and Phansi Museums.

departments.name: Tourism

metrics.name: Support to 40 provincial state-owned tourism attractions

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to 40 provincial state-owned tourism attractions
implementation_detail.detail: In addition to the employment created,  42 SMMEs have so far been supported by the project.
Implementation of the programme has begun and participants are on site.

departments.lead: Tourism monitors and maintenance support to provincial tourism attractions.
departments.paragraph: The Department of Tourism is supporting maintenance activities in 14 provincial tourism attractions and placing tourism monitors at key tourism sites where extra security will enhance accessibility for tourists.

departments.name: Trade, Industry and Competition

implementation_detail.detail: The department exceeded its target for job creation, facilitated by commitment of additional funds internally to the programme. The support from the employment stimulus concluded at the end of March 2021. Most the employed participants were  youth engaged in complex and non-complex jobs within the global business services sector.

The Industrial Development Corporation has completed the request for proposals for Strategic Implementing Partners. The first five SIPs have been appointed, as part of a process that expedited applicants 'at an advanced stage of readiness' who were able to submit applications by an earlier deadline. They are now collaborating with the IDC in the design and development of the central payments and reporting system, while the adjudication of the balance of applications is finalised.

departments.lead: Social Employment Fund - work for the common good
departments.paragraph:
Phase Two is supporting the development of a ‘social employment’ strategy. This expands the traditional definition of public employment (or public works) programmes run directly by the state, to recognise the role that non-state actors already play in creating forms of work that serve the common good. Work 'for the common good’ refers to work that contributes to public goods and services, rather than private ones. This includes a wide array of activities, including care, Early Childhood Development, community safety, placemaking, river cleaning, support to creative initiatives and much more. While many organisations are already engaged in such work, many of their efforts rely on voluntary work which can be hard to sustain. The social employment approach aims to change that: to recognise the public value being created through these efforts and to expand the scale and scope of support to such initiatives. The effect on participants and on communities has the potential to be transformative - it should be designed to be so. This strategy forms part of the dtic's support to the Social and Solidarity Economy. The Industrial Development Corporation is the fund manager.  
In Phase One, the dtic created opportunities in the call centre industry through its Global Business Services (GBS) incentive programme, and exceeded its target.

departments.name: Transport

implementation_detail.detail: Despite numerous challenges faced by provincial departments in the planning phase, projects were implemented and participants contributed to the maintenance of 4,334 kms of rural roads.

departments.paragraph: In Phase One, rural roads programmes were rolled out in most Provinces. Despite numerous challenges faced by provincial departments in the planning phase and implementation, projects are in implementation and appointed participants are contributing to the maintenance of rural roads. To date, 4334 km of roads have maintained. The programme did not receive funds in Phase Two.
